awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Capturing the Stars: Exploring Digitization of Photographic Glass Plates for Scientific Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The historic Yerkes Observatory in Williams Bay Wisconsin has contributed to research and education in astronomy and astrophysics since 1897. The Observatory has over 170,000 astronomical glass photographic plates and observational logbooks which are important both historically and for research, but which are largely inaccessible due to their present geographical location and their rather fragile state. This project will research, analyze and develop both methods and procedures to use financially accessible equipment to digitize the glass plates. It will also work out how to transcribe complex data from the logbooks, and evaluate how best to make all of the plate images and meta-data records accessible and usable by researchers and historians worldwide. The project includes collaboration between librarians and astronomers and provides paid research opportunities to undergraduates. It will facilitate scientific and historical research, and create openly accessible data that will be a source for astronomy education and outreach. 

By creating scalable and cost-effective practices for digitization of astronomical glass plate collections, this work will help to protect and preserve unique and irreplaceable observational archives. These data will be a most valuable contribution to time domain astronomy, and add a wealth of primary source information to the history of astronomy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Yerkes Observatory in Williams Bay, Wisconsin, is the original home of the University of Chicago's Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics. The earliest years paralleled a period of great progress in photographic technology which enabled new discoveries and propelled the advancement of astrophysics. The photographic glass plate negatives produced and studied at Yerkes are a significant part of the canon of work that changed our understanding of the universe, containing more than a century of data valuable to astronomers and historians alike. However, this data is in analog form on the plates, incompatible with modern astronomical tools. 

"Capturing the Stars: Exploring Digitization of Photographic Glass Plates for Scientific Analysis" explored low-cost, accessible methods and procedures for digitizing the plates and unlocking this data. Using an Epson Expression 12000XL graphic arts scanner with a transparency accessory and a Canon EOS 7D Mark II DSLR camera and lightbox, the cross-disciplinary team of astronomers, librarians, and students researched and analyzed digitizations of different plates. Research focused primarily on high-quality plates with large numbers of stars. This work demonstrated that these tools do capture enough precision of position and brightness of celestial objects for meaningful research, opening the door for the digitization of more collections and significantly increasing the availability of historic plates for time-domain studies. Data from this research is available at Knowledge@UChicago, the university?s open access repository https://knowledge.uchicago.edu/search?ln=en&p=yerkes&f=&sf=&so=d&rg=25).

In addition, the logbooks and metadata associated with the plates are important resources for researchers, facilitating searches for plates and understanding the environment in which they were made. The team digitized 66 logbooks and identified 63 more in the University Library Special Collections for future digitization. Automatic optical character recognition for transcription failed on the cursive handwriting in the logbooks, necessitating human intervention. We also developed an efficient voice-to-text transcription strategy focused on transcribing the critical scientific data, rather than a complete transcription of all text. The initial fields to be transcribed include date, plate number, right ascension, declination, and notes, each of which will help astronomers identify plates for research purposes. The goal of this transcription strategy is to facilitate efficient and accurate transcription efforts, support keyword searches of transcribed fields to simplify searching, as well as making the digitized logbooks more accessible. 

Throughout the project, the team collaborated with members of the International Glass Plates Group, a group of scientists, archivists, librarians, and historians with interest in preservation and digitization of astronomical glass plates. This included both presenting research and discussing topics of general interest including metadata schema, alt text for scientific images, and databases among others. Overall, research resulted in two peer-reviewed journal articles and several presentations at conferences and symposia. Most publicly available is the Yerkes Glass Plate Collection within the University of Chicago Library?s Digital Collections (https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/collex/collections/yerkes-plates/about/). This site not only details all of the methods and procedures, but also is where researchers can access all assets, including the 66 digitized logbooks and inventory lists for nearly 25% of the 180,000 plates in the collection. 

Capturing the Stars transforms how the Yerkes plates and logbooks can be used by demonstrating the viability of accessible equipment to digitize historic plates for scientific research, providing researchers access to plate inventories and digitized logbooks, and developing a strategy for logbook transcription. The project supported underrepresented students and established strong relationships between departments at the University of Chicago as well as with others interested in the preservation and digitization of plates. It also established a significant, positive relationship with the Yerkes Future Foundation, the new stewards of Yerkes Observatory. Additionally, this project set the stage for continuing research, including in-depth exploration of the women working at Yerkes and finding a flexible tool to manage metadata and facilitate searching.
